job_title: Direct Care Provider in Weirton, WV
pros: Schedule can be flexible because they are desperate for staff due to high turnover. They also give out occasional bonuses instead of pay raises or benefits for all employees.
cons: So much. Poor management from the top down to HR and to supervisors on the waiver side. There's a lot of shady stuff going on with supervisors, favoritism, Human Resources coercing employees and circling the wagons for long time supervisors, and an overall toxic work environment. Safety of clientele and staff is not a concern for management. They only care about money and being able to bill clients. Pay is ridiculously poor for industry standards. No benefits or paid time off for anyone working under 40 hours a week.

review_title: Great to grow personally, bad to make a career
pros:
-Clients
-Co-workers
-Ton to learn about community resources
-Feel good about the lives you save/help
-Got to practice clinical skills with a hard population of clients
cons:
-Management is money crazed
-Company seems reluctant to grow new ideas and preys on clients to sustain itself.
-If you are young, you will be overworked (60-70 hr/ week)
-Awful private benefits- HR will try to get you on Medicaid because your pay is so low
-Your sick days/ personal days are the same and you get less than other companies.
-You will always see ineffective treatment practices (SA and MH groups together, personality disorders placed with SA, Anxiety, and depression) Though some of these populations see little change, it is even less with "money-saving", unethical treatment practices (unethical because practices do not follow empirical, recent research in tx)
-Company kisses the ground of the old CEO who changed the mentality of it from a community-assistance organization to a money making machine; though he has since resigned after a scandal was brought to light, the company still harbors people with the same mentality in higher-up positions.

review_title: While I enjoyed many of my co-workers, management was more concerned with making money than helping others.
pros: Many of those working here are great people, and genuinely want to help the community and those suffering most.
cons: Upper management are very much only concerned with bringing money into the coffers. I often had to argue about policies to keep people who were suicidal from being allowed to go outside to smoke beside the road even though earlier that day they had tried to commit suicide by throwing themselves in front of a moving car. I have also seen them discharge suicidal clients with no insurance early so they could get a drug abuser with Medicaid onto the crisis unit.
